#Text=Scottish gamekeeper jailed for bird crime in national first
#Text=Tuesday , January 13 , 2015
#Text=A Sheriff in Aberdeen yesterday jailed gamekeeper George Mutch for crimes against birds of prey .
#Text=It is believed to be the first time anybody has been imprisoned for raptor persecution in Scotland .
#Text=Wildlife criminals must expect no sympathy from now on
#Text=— RSPB
#Text=Mutch , 48 , killed a protected goshawk , and used illegal traps to capture a buzzard and a second goshawk .
#Text=He was convicted last month of four offences , which he committed in 2012 in Aberdeenshire .
#Text=The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds ( RSPB ) used hidden cameras to record Mutch 's crimes , one of the first times such footage has featured in a Scottish wildlife trial .
#Text=The video shows Mutch remove a juvenile goshawk from one trap and beat it to death with a stick .
#Text=He removes the other goshawk and the buzzard , putting them in sacks which he then walks away with .
#Text=Their fate is unknown .
#Text=Sheriff Noel McPartlin called Mutch 's conduct " a determined course of action .

#Text= Sara Shaw , Scotland 's procurator fiscal ( prosecutor ) for wildlife crime , explained " Goshawks in particular are rare birds : the court heard evidence in this case that there are only about 150 nesting pairs in Scotland .

column1: #Text=" She said the law was there " to preserve Scotland 's natural heritage , including the wildlife that forms part of it .
#Text="

#Text=RSPB Scotland 's Duncan Orr-Ewing called the sentence a  historic , landmark result " and " a turning point , sending a clear message to those determined to flout our laws " .

column1: #Text=Landowners ' body Scottish Land and Estates also had no sympathy : " The illegal killing of any bird of prey is unacceptable and anyone who engages in such activity can , rightly , expect to feel the full weight of the law .

#Text= We would like to thank the Crown Office and Police Scotland for helping to bring this case to a successful conviction , as well as the exemplary work of the RSPB Scotland investigations team " said Orr-Ewing .

column1: #Text=He added " Wildlife criminals must expect no sympathy from now on .
